description:
Fonsecaea multimorphosa is a species of fungus belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It was first isolated from a clinical specimen in Brazil and designated the strain CBS 102226.

Fonsecaea multimorphosa is a dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungus that exhibits a variety of morphological forms, including yeast-like, filamentous, and sclerotic bodies. The fungus is characterized by the production of dark-colored hyphae and the formation of chlamydospores (thick-walled resting spores).

This species is considered an opportunistic human pathogen and has been associated with various types of phaeohyphomycosis, a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous fungi. Infections with F. multimorphosa can manifest as subcutaneous, cutaneous, or disseminated forms, and are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals.

Molecular identification and phylogenetic analysis have revealed that F. multimorphosa is closely related to other species within the Fonsecaea genus, which are known to cause chromoblastomycosis, a chronic and difficult-to-treat fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues.

Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical management of infections caused by this particular species of Fonsecaea.
